0001.title: Decentralized Data Structures
0001.description: The decentralized web relies on unique data structures and linking strategies. Learn about the benefits of hashing, content addressing, DAG and Merkle Trees!

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how users share files on IPFS, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: Decentralized Web Primer: The Power of Content-Addressing
resources.description: A beginner-friendly primer on content addressing from Matt Zumwalt.

resources.title: The Next Internet Revolution
resources.description: In this excerpt from his TedX Talk, Juan Benet explains how the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) uses content addressing to reframe our model for sharing knowledge.

resources.title: Why is Decentralized and Distributed File Storage Critical for a Better Web?
resources.description: Juan Benet, Jesse Clayburgh, and Matt Zumwalt of Protocol Labs explain how advances in distributed data storage and strong alignment of market incentives are combining to create a more secure and efficient web.

resources.title: Instructions for Saving Endangered Data
resources.description: Matt Zumwalt of IPFS explains why data isn't safe on the centralized web and how IPFS can be used to protect it.

resources.title: HTTP is Obsolete. It's Time for the Distributed, Permanent Web.
resources.description: Kyle Drake of Neocities explores the downsides of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).

resources.title: Anatomy of a CID
resources.description: Dive deeper into how CIDs are constructed in IPFS, from multihash and multicodec prefixes to CID versions. (No coding required.)

resources.title: IPFS: Mutable File System (MFS)
resources.description: Explore the Mutable File System (MFS), which lets you work with files and directories in IPFS as if you were using a traditional name-based file system. (This tutorial includes JavaScript code challenges.)

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: Use the IPFS DAG API to create create verifiable links between dataset with Content Identifiers (CIDs). (This tutorial includes JavaScript code challenges.)

0002.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
0002.description: Store, fetch, and create verifiable links between peer-hosted datasets using the IPFS DAG API and CIDs. Itâ€™s graphs with friends!

resources.title: Blogging on the Decentralized Web
resources.description: Ready for a bigger challenge with the IPFS DAG API? Use CIDs to build and update a complex web of data.

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added data to IPFS? This IPFS Camp 2019 course explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Ready to deal with more than primitives? Explore the API custom-built for efficient handling of files in IPFS.

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added data to IPFS? This IPFS Camp 2019 course explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Ready to deal with more than primitives? Explore the API custom-built for efficient handling of files in IPFS.

0004.title: IPFS: Mutable File System
0004.description: The Mutable File System (MFS) lets you work with files and directories as if you were using a traditional name-based file system.
0004.updateMessage: Version `0.41` of `js-ipfs` has introduced some major changes, most notably by introducing Async Iterables. You can learn more about the updates here: [IPFS Blog - The Async Await Refactor](https://blog.ipfs.io/2020-02-01-async-await-refactor/). This means that **some code challenge solutions have changed**. We recommend re-visiting this tutorial to learn about the updated methods and complete the revised challenges!

resources.title: JS-IPFS Files API
resources.description: Notice that these docs contain two sections, one for top-level methods relevant to files and one for the Mutable File System (MFS) you learned about in this tutorial.

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports. It also introduces some the joys and pitfalls of the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added files to IPFS? This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Explore the other half of the IPFS Files API, where you'll add and retrieve files and read their contents without the abstraction layer of the Mutable File System.

resources.title: Browser MFS Demo
resources.description: Try out MFS methods in your broswer and watch your file directory change as you go.

resources.title: Jeromy Coffee Talks: Files API
resources.description: Wondering how the Mutable File System (MFS) can treat immutable data as though it's mutable? Jeromy Johnson of Protocol Labs explains the abstraction that makes it possible.

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: You've seen the IPFS Files API. Now explore the IPFS DAG API, where you'll use CIDs to create verifiable links between datasets.

0005.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
0005.description: The IPFS Regular Files API provides a way to store and share files in a peer-to-peer storage system.
0005.updateMessage: Version `0.41` of `js-ipfs` has introduced some major changes, most notably by introducing Async Iterables. You can learn more about the updates here: [IPFS Blog - The Async Await Refactor](https://blog.ipfs.io/2020-02-01-async-await-refactor/). This means that **some code challenge solutions have changed**. We recommend re-visiting this tutorial to learn about the updated methods and complete the revised challenges!

resources.title: JS-IPFS Files API
resources.description: Notice that these docs contain two sections, one for top-level methods relevant to files, which we learned about in this tutorial, and one for the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports. It also introduces some the joys and pitfalls of the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added files to IPFS? This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Mutable File System (MFS)
resources.description: Wish adding files to IPFS felt more like using a traditional name-based file system? Explore the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: You've seen the IPFS Files API. Now explore the IPFS DAG API, where you'll use CIDs to create verifiable links between datasets.

0006.title: Anatomy of a CID
0006.description: A content identifier, or CID, is a label used to point to data stored on distributed information systems including IPFS, IPLD, libp2p, and Filecoin. It doesnâ€™t indicate where the content is stored, but it forms a kind of address based on the content itself.

resources.title: How IPFS Deals With Files: Anatomy of a CID
resources.description: Watch the talk that inspired this tutorial! In Part 2 of this core course from IPFS Camp 2019, Alan Shaw explains the anatomy of a CID.

resources.title: CID Inspector
resources.description: Paste a CID into this handy web app for a human-readable breakdown of its multibase, multicodec, multihash and version.

resources.title: Hashes
resources.description: Learn more about cryptographic hashes in the official IPFS docs.

resources.title: Multiformats
resources.description: Explore Multiformats, a collection of protocols that future-proof systems, including CID, multihash, multibase and multicodec.

resources.title: Multihash
resources.description: Learn more about the multihash protocol for differentiating outputs from various well-established hash functions, addressing size and encoding considerations.

resources.title: Content Identifier (CID) Specification
resources.description: Review the specification for CID, the self-describing content-addressed identifier for distributed systems like IPFS and IPLD.
